snippet.title: Addy Osmani | Solve AI Context Failures in React with MCP and Tooling This Way
snippet.description:
üìâ AI success rates drop to 20% on real-world tasks due to the "Complexity Cliff." Stop untangling hallucinations and solve Context Failures in React using Model Context Protocol (MCP).

In this talk, Addy Osmani, Engineering Manager at Google, reveals the engineering stack needed to move from chaotic "vibe coding" to reliable production quality.

You will learn how to:
‚úÖ Fix Design Flaws: Force models to follow your design system using Skills.
‚úÖ Inject Truth: Use MCP servers (Next.js, Chrome DevTools) to give agents access to runtime state.
‚úÖ Architect Control: Implement a closed-loop workflow that validates code before you commit.

üëâ Subscribe for more insights from top tech leaders!

üìå Follow the link to watch the full version of all the conference talks, QnA‚Äôs with speakers and hands-on workshop recordings:  
üîó https://gitnation.com/events/react-summit-us-2025?utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=AddyOsmaniTalk

üîó https://reactsummit.com/?utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=AddyOsmaniTalk

snippet.title: Building Complex Systems with AI: SSH, Tailscale, and Coding Agents | Case Study
snippet.description:
üõë Stop guessing with non-deterministic AI code.

Ken Wheeler, Ex-Director of Open Source at Formidable, deconstructs the "Vibe Coding" trend, transforming it from a meme into a rigorous architectural approach. He proves that coding with AI isn‚Äôt fundamentally different ‚Äî it requires combining deep domain expertise with agentic workflows to build verifiable systems.

In this video:
üîê The "Black Box" Solution: How to leverage Generative AI without losing control over code quality.
üõ†Ô∏è Agentic Workflows: Moving beyond simple token prediction to deterministic tool usage.
üì° Real-World Case Study: Orchestrating AI agents via SSH and Tailscale to build a functional hardware-software (IoT) integration.

snippet.title: React Compiler: Auto-memoization at Build Time | Addy Osmani | Discussion
snippet.description:
Is useMemo truly dead? Can we finally trust the React Compiler to handle performance automatically?

In this session from React Summit US 2025, industry leaders:
üí´ Addy Osmani, Engineering Manager at Google Chrome
üí´ Shaundai Person, Senior Software Engineer at Netflix
üí´ Seth Webster, Executive Director at React Foundation
üí´ Nicolas Gallagher, Engineering Manager at Meta, React Native
üí´ Amy Dutton, Lead Developer at Prefect
üí´ Mark Erikson, Redux Maintainer, Senior Principal Engineer at Echobind

They debate the reality of shifting to "auto-memoization," discussing whether the new Compiler truly eliminates the need for manual tuning or if it introduces new architectural challenges for production apps.

üìå Follow the link to watch the full version of all the conference talks, QnA‚Äôs with speakers and hands-on workshop recordings:

snippet.title: Case | React Strict DOM: How Meta Solves UI Fragmentation with Web APIs | Nicolas Gallagher
snippet.description:
‚ùå Stop maintaining separate codebases for Web and Native. ‚úÖ Learn how Meta builds native apps using standard Web APIs ‚Äî achieving ~60% code reuse without WebViews.

Nicolas Gallagher (Meta Engineer and Creator of both React Native for Web and React Strict DOM) presents a unified architecture ‚Äî React Strict DOM. It leverages a unified API based on standard HTML to drive truly native rendering on mobile and HTML on the web.

This talk covers the Facebook VR case study, showing how to eliminate UI fragmentation, optimize AI code generation, and deploy universal features with zero visual regressions üî•

snippet.title: Vibe Coding Costs You 20% Productivity | Shawn Swyx Wang
snippet.description:
"You are here expecting a talk on Generative UI. This is not that talk... because I failed." ¬©
This failure revealed a harsh reality: the "productivity boost" from AI coding agents is often an illusion.
:point_right::skin-tone-2: Instead of speed, "vibe coding" is creating massive technical debt. Data shows that blind automation lowers actual productivity by 20%.
In this video, Shawn Swyx Wang reveals the data-backed way to fix this.

üìå Follow the link to watch the full version of all the conference talks, QnA‚Äôs with speakers and hands-on workshop recordings:  
üîó https://gitnation.com/events/react-summit-us-2025?utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=ShawnSwyxWangTalk

02:42 - Why you must keep the steering wheel (The "Self-Driving" Trap)
05:06 - When AI deletes your Prod DB | and what is ‚Äú2 Devs = 50 Devs of Debt‚Äù
06:02 - The Illusion of Speed: Why actual productivity dropped by 20% in trials
07:25 - Solution 1: Interactive Planning (Don't let the agent lock you out)
09:46 - Solution 2: Solution 2: Escaping the "Async Valley of Death"

snippet.title: Unlock Full End-to-End Development with CDK | Using AWS Directly
snippet.description:

Stop wasting time managing servers and relying on third-party wrappers. üëâüèª Provision AWS infrastructure directly using your TypeScript skills to unlock full end-to-end development.

Erik Hanchett, Senior Developer Advocate at Amazon and Author of Vue.js in Action explains ‚úÖ how to bypass intermediaries and offload compute to Lambda without maintaining EC2 instances or VPNs. 

‚úÖ You will learn to use the AWS Cloud Development Kit (CDK) and Amplify Gen 2 to define infrastructure as code, allowing you to build scalable, serverless applications efficiently.

snippet.title: Video Optimization for the Web: The Missing Piece in Lighthouse
snippet.description:
Talk: Rahul Nanwani - "Video Optimization for the Web: The Missing Piece in Lighthouse", React Summit US 2025

Video is everywhere on the web, from hero banners to product videos to full-blown streaming. However, while Lighthouse reports issues related to images, scripts, and more, it doesn't really address video performance. That means streaming can suffer for end users, resulting in buffering and slow starts, while businesses incur huge data transfer costs due to unoptimized delivery.

In this lightning talk, we'll explore some quick wins every developer should know: optimizing video size and format, optimizing streaming for every device and network, and different video loading strategies to improve performance. In just seven minutes, you'll leave with a toolkit to make your videos load faster, play smoother, and feel as polished as the rest of your app, closing a significant gap that performance audits often overlook.

Watch the full talk in 1080p on GitNation website: https://gitnation.com/contents/video-optimization-for-the-web-the-missing-piece-in-lighthouse

Follow the link to watch the full version of all the conference talks, QnA‚Äôs with speakers and hands-on workshop recordings ‚Üí https://gitnation.com/events/react-summit-us-2025

Timestamps:

snippet.title: Why Writing a Pinch-to-Zoom Component Is Harder Than You Think
snippet.description:
Talk: Oli Legat - "Why Writing a Pinch-to-Zoom Component Is Harder Than You Think", React Summit US 2025

At first glance, building a pinch-to-zoom and pan component in React seems simple. After all, the browser‚Äôs gesture events are already there. But when you need realistic, design-friendly motion and the ability to zoom axes independently, the problem gets much trickier. In this talk, I‚Äôll share how we approached this challenge in our AG Charts React component: from the pitfalls of na√Øve implementations, to the realisation that pan and zoom are mathematically identical problems. You‚Äôll see how some pen & paper algebra unlocked a precise and intuitive gesture system where X and Y scales update independently‚Äîkept in sync with React state‚Äîdelivering smooth interactions beyond what you get in maps or images.

Watch the full talk with Q&A on GitNation website: https://gitnation.com/contents/why-writing-a-pinch-to-zoom-component-is-harder-than-you-think

Follow the link to watch the full version of all the conference talks, QnA‚Äôs with speakers and hands-on workshop recordings ‚Üí https://gitnation.com/events/react-summit-us-2025

snippet.title: Plug and Play Design: Building Extendable React Applications
snippet.description:
Talk: Mateusz Jagodzi≈Ñski - "Plug and Play Design: Building Extendable React Applications", React Summit US 2025

In large React projects, feature toggles and conditional builds can quickly become messy. What if entire features could be added‚Äîor removed‚Äîjust by dropping a folder in or out of your project? In this talk, I‚Äôll show how a plugin architecture makes React applications more modular and easier to maintain, with practical code examples from our product.

Watch the full talk with Q&A on GitNation website: https://gitnation.com/contents/plug-and-play-design-building-extendable-react-applications

snippet.title: Fixing React full-stack with zero-syntax type safety | by Tanner Linsley, creator of React Query
snippet.description:
Tired of "meta-framework fatigue"? Tanner Linsley, creator of React Query, reveals a ‚Äúclient-first" architecture that finally fixes full-stack React.

Experience end-to-end type safety with zero boilerplate. In this deep dive, Tanner demonstrates how TanStack Start leverages the Router to merge the speed of SPAs with the power of Server Functions. Learn how to build type-safe, isomorphic apps that scale.

üîó Follow the link to watch the full version of all the conference talks, Q&A‚Äôs with speakers and hands-on workshop recordings: https://gitnation.com/events/react-summit-us-2025utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=react-summit-US-talks-post-1-12-2025
